question: In neonates, what causes acute pyogenic meningitis?

Which of these most accurately describes stroke?

answers.option: Cerebrovascular diseases caused by damage to blood vessels

question: Which of the following is not a feature of acute bacterial meningitis?

answers.option: Cerebrospinal fluid with increased glucose content

Which of the following symptoms will be the result of a lesion of the intermediate zone of the cerebellum?

What are the histopathological findings in Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease?

answers.option: Decreased muscle tone in the right upper and lower limbs
Swaying left to right with eyes closed

question: Which of the following is correct regarding a watershed infarct?

answers.option: A paradoxical occurrence in which ischemic area becomes infused with cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and life-threatening cerebral edema ensues
It is seen after hypotensive episodes
It may occur at the borderzone between anterior and middle cerebral arteries
It occurs when there is liquefactive necrosis
It occurs due to hyperviscosity of blood

question: What is the pathophysiology behind schizophrenia?

answers.option: Miller Fisher is a common variant
It is a non inflammatory disorder
It is a chronic demyelinating mononeuropathy multiplex
It is an acute demyelinating polyradiculoneuropathy

question: Which of the following infections causes tabes dorsalis?
What is the most likely cause of an increase in proteins in cerebrospinal (CSF)?
Chronic hypertension is the most critical risk factor for developing which of the following types of brain aneurysms?

A 50-year-old patient presents with tuberculous meningitis for the past 10 years. Which of the following is most likely to be his viral history?

An 8-month-old baby is brought to the pediatric emergency with a history of high-grade fever, fits, and refusal to take feed. On examination, he has a 102 °F temperature with altered consciousness. On cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) examination, cells are 1200/ml and mostly polymorphonuclear neutrophils. Which type of meningitis is it most likely to be?

A 70-year-old man has a 2-day history of a generalized, progressively worsening headache and increasing obtundation. He now complains of stiffness in his neck. On physical examination, vital signs include a temperature of 37°C, a pulse of 85/minute, respiration 23/minute, and blood pressure 130/85 mm Hg. A CBC reveals a WBC count of 16,850/microliter. A lumbar puncture yields cloudy cerebrospinal fluid with raised glucose, decreased protein, cell count of 3800 WBCs (95% polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMNs) and 5% mononuclear), and 122 RBCs. He receives antibiotic therapy and improves. Which of the following is the most likely long-term complication from this man's current disease?
Which of the following tests is most suitable for the diagnosis of spinal cord lesions?
Which of the following is inappropriate regarding Sydenham's chorea?

answers.option: Patient usually recovers spontaneously in 1 to 4 months
It is a typical exaggeration of associated movements during voluntary activity
It is accompanied by muscular hypertonia
It is a complication of rheumatic fever
It is characterized by fine, disorganized and random movements of extremities, face and tongue

question: A person presents to the clinic and has difficulty in balancing and has slurred speech. The lesion is present in which of the following?

A 39-year-old woman has had a severe headache for 3 days. On physical examination, she is afebrile and normotensive. Fundoscopic examination shows papilledema on the right. One day later, she has right pupillary dilation and impaired ocular movement. Which of the following lesions best explains these findings?

A 15-year-old girl presented to the outpatient department with complaints of headaches for the past 8 months. Over a 2-week period, she has a generalized seizure. On physical examination, there is no papilledema or movement disorder. Computed tomography (CT) scan of the head shows a 2 cm mass in the right frontal lobe and shows evidence of recent and remote hemorrhage. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A child suffers from non-communicating hydrocephalus. Which of the following is a characteristic of non-communicating hydrocephalus?

A 39-year-old female patient presents to the outpatient department with a severe headache for the last 3 days. On physical examination, she is afebrile and normotensive. Fundoscopic examination shows papilledema in the right eye. She was admitted to the hospital for further testing. A day later, she develops right pupillary dilation with impaired ocular movement. These findings are best explained by which of the following lesions?

A female infant born after a full-term pregnancy weighing 3.4kg has an enlarged head with the occipitofrontal circumference (OFC) being 49.5 cm. A cranial ultrasound reveals bilateral ventriculomegaly. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old male who has a history of HIV is admitted to the neurology ward with signs and symptoms of encephalitis. Which of the following is a characteristic histopathological finding of HIV encephalitis?

answers.option: Microglial nodules and multinucleated giant cells

question: Which of the following is not a risk factor for encephalitis?

answers.option: People with a strong immune system
Children under the age of 1 year
People with a weak immune system

question: A 50-year-old female patient who is a known case of an autoimmune disorder visits the neurology clinic with complaints of fatigue, tingling, numbness, muscle weakness, and muscle spasms. CSF analysis reveals oligoclonal bands. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this case?

A 5-month-old boy is brought to the outpatient clinic with complaints of global developmental delay, generalized weakness of the body, and jerky eye movement. There is also a family history of his 5-year-old brother having the same complaints. MRI scans of the brain reveal symmetrical lesions. Genetic studies reveal a mutation in the ABCD1 gene located at the X chromosome. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 5-year-old boy is admitted to the neurology ward with complaints of headache, photophobia, and neck rigidity. He is a suspected case of meningitis. Which of the following is the best diagnostic investigation for meningitis?
A 1-year-old girl is diagnosed with bacterial meningitis. Which of the following findings in the CSF analysis are suggestive of bacterial meningitis?

A young male patient presents to the emergency department in an unconscious state. The parents give a history of him swimming in a pool for the last few days. CSF analysis reveals small flask-shaped amoeba. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this case?

A 60-year-old male patient with a history of hypertension for the last 10 years is brought to the emergency department in an unconscious state. History also reveals that the patient is non-compliant with his medication for hypertension. MRI and CT scan brain show a lobar hemorrhage. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this condition?
A woman develops right-sided body weakness at night that later resolves. The next morning she comes to the clinic concerned about what happened. What could be the cause?

Which of the following regions of the spinal cord is affected in a patient with polio?
A baby is born with low birth weight, and a CT scan shows periventricular calcification. Which infection is most likely responsible for this finding?

A man had an accident in which he hit the front windshield of his vehicle. MRI showed minor cerebral contusion but he had no symptoms until after a month when he presented to the clinic with headaches, irritability, and was acting strangely. Which cerebrovascular condition best explains these symptoms?
Which of the following is deficient in Alzheimer's disease?

A patient presents with a "pill-rolling" tremor at rest in the right hand. Which of the following diseases is most likely?

A 24-year-old man fell down the stairs during a fight and lost consciousness. After regaining consciousness, he visited a restaurant but lost consciousness again while eating, about an hour later. Upon being taken to the ER, a CT scan of the brain was performed. Physical examination revealed fixed and dilated pupils. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 65-year-old woman with a history of hypertension suddenly experienced right-sided loss of sensation while she was watching television in the evening. She noticed the numbness and weakness lasted for about 20 minutes but gradually improved, and by the time she went to bed, she felt completely normal. The next morning, she had no lingering symptoms but was concerned about what had happened. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A patient with increased intracranial pressure (ICP) has the following vital signs: blood pressure 99/60, heart rate 65, temperature 101.6 'F, respiration rate 14, and oxygen saturation of 95%. ICP reading is 21 mmHg. Based on these findings, what is the most appropriate initial step in managing this patient?

answers.option: Administer PRN dose of a vasopressor
Remove extra blankets and give the patient a cool bath

question: A patient who experienced a cerebral hemorrhage is at risk for developing increased intracranial pressure (ICP). Which of the following signs and symptoms is the earliest indicator of the patient developing this complication?

answers.option: Mostly seen in adolescents, resulting in cognitive impairment and seizures
Is a common opportunistic viral pathogen in individuals
Mainly affects pregnant women, leading to fetal periventricular necrosis and brain destruction
Primarily in elderly individuals, resulting in peripheral neuropathy and encephalitis
Occurs predominantly in infants and immuno-compromised individuals, leading to microcephaly and periventricular calcification

question: A 19-year-old college student presents with fever, rash, and neck stiffness. CSF analysis shows increased neutrophils, decreased glucose, and increased protein. Which organism is most likely responsible?

answers.option: One who is admitted with a traumatic brain injury
One who is recently experienced a myocardial infarction
One who is post-op from eye surgery
One who is experiencing severe hypotension
One who is recently been diagnosed as case of multiple sclerosis

question: A 33-year-old woman with a diffuse macular rash presents with headache, fever, and neck stiffness. CSF analysis reveals lymphocytic pleocytosis, normal glucose, and slightly elevated protein. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A 38-year-old HIV-positive man presents with a headache and vision changes. Indian ink staining of the CSF reveals encapsulated yeasts. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

Which of the following shows a compensatory increase in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) volume due to brain tissue loss?
Saccular aneurysms are the most frequently occurring type of intracranial aneurysm. What percentage of these occur in the anterior circulation?

A 25-year-old man presents to the outpatient department after falling from a ladder. The MRI reveals a skull fracture with a hematoma which is compressing the brain. The dura appears to be peeling off of the skull. Which type of hemorrhage is occurring?
